author: Maura Forrest; The Canadian Press
title: Quebec premier hints at expanding financial aid program for disaster victims - Prince George Citizen
text: MONTREAL — Nearly a week after torrential rain battered Quebec, the contents of people's basements are spilling across their lawns as they wait for garbage trucks to cart away their waterlogged furniture and ruined belongings. In Louiseville, a community of 7,000 people near the St. Lawrence River northeast of Montreal, Mayor Yvon Deshaies says people are doing their best to clean out their homes before mould sets in. About 300 basements in the municipality flooded, he said, some with up to four or five feet of water. "This has never happened before," he said. "It's terrible." Further up the river, in nearby Yamachiche, Mayor Paul Carbonneau says garbage pickup continued until 10 p.m. on Wednesday. He's hoping the cleanup will be finished on Friday for the roughly 100 homes that were flooded. Now that the water has receded and the most urgent part of the crisis is over, Deshaies and Carbonneau — and many people across a large swath of the province that was hit by up to 200 millimetres of rain last Friday — are starting to worry about money. Who will help them pay to fix the damage? During a visit to Louiseville on Thursday, Quebec Premier François Legault told reporters his top priorities after the storm were restoring power to the 550,000 customers left in the dark and fixing damaged roads that left hundreds of houses isolated. Now, though, "we're dealing with money," he said. "The problem that remains … is the question of financial compensation for people who were flooded." Legault suggested the province may temporarily expand its financial assistance program for disaster victims to include sewer backups, which have been excluded until now because they're typically covered by private insurance. The government program has only compensated homeowners for water damage caused by overland flooding, but the premier said that needs to be revisited. "Why was there a sewer backup? It's because there was a flood," he said. "So at a certain point you have to use common sense." Deshaies said he welcomes the possibility of more government aid. "I want everyone to be able to access the program," he said, adding that he believes the government should pay the difference between private insurance coverage and the full cost of repairs. "I would like people not to lose money." Legault didn't offer any details about how the program might be expanded or who would be eligible. An expansion of the province's disaster financial assistance fund would be a "major" change — and likely a very expensive one, said Alain Mailhot, a professor of urban hydrology at Quebec's national scientific research institute. "There's a problem, I agree with the premier," he said of the number of people dealing with sewer backups. "It's not that you shouldn't do it, but putting that into place seems like a big puzzle." Quebec's disaster assistance program is already in high demand. A 2021 audit found a "considerable increase" in the number of applicants and in the amount of funds paid out in recent years. After heavy spring flooding in 2017, the program paid out $285 million to people in 293 municipalities across the province. That bill paled in comparison to the $426 million paid out after even worse flooding in 2019. Last year, there were 35 weather events that left at least one Quebec community eligible for disaster assistance — more than any other year since at least 2010. Most of those involved heavy rainfall. So far this year, there have been 21 such events. Many municipalities have had repeated episodes of rain and flooding in recent years. Nearly half of the 123 communities eligible for disaster assistance following Friday's rainfall have been eligible for government funds at least five times since 2010. Fifteen of them have been on the list 10 times or more. Louiseville and Yamachiche are among that group, though they're most often hit by spring meltwater, not torrential rain. Mailhot said flooding is now happening more frequently following summer storms, rather than just during the spring thaw. "Climate models tell us that this kind of situation, unfortunately, risks happening more often," he said. Pascale Biron, a geography professor at Concordia University, said that in urban areas prone to sewer backups, cities can build sponge parks and green roofs to help absorb water and prevent sewers from overflowing. In the interim, she said, it's "good news" for people dealing with sewer backups if the government decides to offer more money. "I have a lot of sympathy for people who are in that situation, because they have zero control," she said. "But on the other hand, I could see that if you open that can of worms, then that could be costly, because it really happens a lot." On Thursday, Legault had to defend himself for not having visited flood-stricken communities until almost one week after the record-breaking rainfall. Speaking to reporters for the first time since the storm, he said he'd been focused on the widespread power outages and washed-out roads in the first days after the rain. "I think I did what I had to do," he said. This report by The Canadian Press was first published Aug. 15, 2024. Maura Forrest, The Canadian Press

text: Afloat by Romardro Henderson: A Gripping Tale of Survival and the Quest for Manhood Rising author Romardro Henderson captivates readers with his latest novel, Afloat, a gripping story of adventure, resilience, and the quest for manhood. Now available on Amazon, Afloat invites readers on a harrowing journey across the open sea, where a young adolescent's desire to prove himself becomes a battle for survival. In Afloat, Henderson introduces us to a young boy from a coastal village who yearns to demonstrate his worthiness as a man. Determined to outperform the seasoned fishermen in his family, including his father, the protagonist embarks on a solo fishing expedition. However, the journey quickly turns treacherous as he becomes lost at sea, facing the perils of dehydration, starvation, and hallucinations. As the boy confronts his deepest fears, he realizes that the ocean is not the only danger sharks circle ominously, symbolizing the relentless challenges that test his will to survive. Henderson's powerful storytelling and vivid descriptions plunge readers into the heart of the protagonist's struggle, evoking a deep sense of empathy and suspense. Afloat is more than just a survival tale; it is a profound exploration of the human spirit, the importance of family, and the rites of passage that define us. "Afloat is a story about more than survival," says Romardro Henderson. "It's about the journey every young person must take to find their place in the world, to confront their fears, and to realize that strength comes not just from proving oneself to others, but from understanding and accepting oneself." About the Author Romardro Henderson is a talented new voice in literature, known for his ability to weave intense narratives that resonate with readers of all ages. Afloat is his latest work, showcasing his skill in creating stories that are both heart-pounding and deeply meaningful. Afloat is now available for purchase on Amazon. title: PMI Consultant Evolves into Universal Talk Solutions to Address Surge in Language Service Demand | Markets | bigspringherald.com
text:
Florida - PMI Consultant, a cornerstone in business consulting, proudly unveils a strategic evolution to meet the evolving needs of its clientele. Bolstered by a remarkable surge in demand for language services, PMI Consultant is embarking on a forward-thinking transformation, creating a specialized division—Universal Talk Solutions—solely devoted to delivering comprehensive linguistic solutions.
The genesis of this transformative move is rooted in a substantial shift in demand dynamics. The year 2023 witnessed an unprecedented sevenfold increase in interpretation cases compared to business consulting, prompting a proactive response from PMI Consultant. Recognizing this significant trend, the company made the strategic decision to establish Universal Talk Solutions as an independent entity under the PMI umbrella.
"As PMI Consultant, we've always been dedicated to delivering exceptional business consulting and support to our community. The landscape changed dramatically in 2023 when we observed a sevenfold increase in demand for language services over consulting cases. This pivotal realization became the driving force behind the decision to create Universal Talk Solutions," explains Pedro Raphael, CEO at PMI Consultant.
Effective November 2023, Universal Talk Solutions will stand as a distinct division, catering exclusively to the rising demand for translation of documents, onsite interpretation, and phone interpretation for medical and business needs. This strategic shift positions the company to better streamline and enhance the delivery of language services, acknowledging the unique challenges businesses face in today's interconnected world.
"Universal Talk Solutions is more than a new name; it's a reflection of our dedication to providing seamless communication solutions," adds Pedro Raphael.
With a team of over 500 interpreters and translators, Universal Talk Solutions is well-equipped to meet the diverse and growing language requirements of its clients. The division is supported by cutting-edge technological solutions, including a proprietary CRM system, ensuring efficiency and precision in every language service provided.
"The decision to create Universal Talk Solutions was not only a response to demand but a strategic move to deliver language solutions with the same dedication and excellence our clients expect. This new division embodies our commitment to providing specialized linguistic services tailored to the evolving needs of our community," adds Pedro Raphael.
For more information about Universal Talk Solutions and its range of language services, please visit https://universaltalksolutions.com or contact (855) 392-2122.
About PMI Consultant:
PMI Consultant has been a reputable provider of business consulting and support services, earning trust within the community. Acknowledging the surge in demand for language services, PMI Consultant expands its offerings with the creation of Universal Talk Solutions, a dedicated division focused on specialized language services. For more information, visit https://universaltalksolutions.com

author: Diego Gutiérrez
title: La Cybertruck fue el mayor capricho de la 'cabezoner\u00eda' de Elon Musk, pero su burbuja ya se ha desinflado
text: Atrás quedan los días en los que podías comprar un Tesla Cybertruck y, justo en el momento de recibir el vehículo, venderlo por el doble que te costó o incluso más. La futurista pick-up de Tesla generó una expectación brutal antes de su lanzamiento y durante los primeros meses de su lanzamiento, pero la burbuja que tuvo ha estallado y seguramente no vuelva a ser lo que una vez fue.La Cybertruck pasará a la historia como uno de los coches más rompedores de la historia en términos de diseño. En una era donde algunos critican ciertas tendencias de diseño o acusan falta de originalidad, la Cybertruck fue algo totalmente rompedor. Un verdadero capricho de Elon Musk, que se empeñó en sacar al mercado un vehículo con este diseño, incluso con las dificultades que suponía su fabricación y los dolores de cabeza que podía generar al equipo de homologaciones.RelacionadoElon Musk llega a la Casa Blanca para aportar el toque Tesla en la administración de Donald TrumpHay dos circunstancias que explican el estallido de la burbuja: la acumulación de stock y el precio en el mercado de segunda mano. Tesla dejó de vender la lucrativa Foundation Series, por la que pedían un sobreprecio de unos 20.000 dólares, para centrarse en versiones más normales. Podrías pensar que, siendo más barata y teniendo en cuenta que había "millones" de reservas, se las están quitando de las manos. Pero no.El Cybertruck ha causado un gran revuelo en todo el mundo por su diseño y prestaciones.Lo cierto es que Tesla ya tiene en su inventario web unidades de la Cybertruck. Todavía son pocas, pero empiezan a aparecer. Aunque dejó de vender la carísima edición de lanzamiento Foundation Series, las versiones disponibles siguen siendo tope de gama y quizá eso explique (al menos en parte) que no tengan suficiente demanda. Si en vez del inventario quieres una nueva de fábrica, el plazo de entrega previsto es entre noviembre y diciembre. Apenas dos semanas. El precio: 85.490 dólares antes de incentivos.RelacionadoTesla, el mayor fabricante de eléctricos, sorprende al apoyar la eliminación de las ayudas para sus propios cochesEl otro punto clave está en los precios del mercado de segunda mano. En las primeras semanas se desató locura y se llegaron a anunciar por un cuarto de millón de dólares. Hubo gente que especuló con ellas: ¡podías sacarle el doble de lo que costaba nueva! Ahora, sin embargo, empiezan a conocerse casos de lo contrario: las Cybertruck empiezan a venderse por debajo de lo que cuesta nueva, como es normal en la inmensa mayoría de coches de producción.No es el único caso de demanda débil. Aunque las pick-ups son los vehículos más populares en Estados Unidos, una auténtica fiebre en aquel país, la demanda de pick-ups eléctricas está en niveles bastante bajos. Rivian tuvo que recolocar cierta parte de su producción y priorizar el SUV, Ford redujo la producción de la F-150 Lightning y General Motors sólo ha vendido 5.000 unidades de la Chevy Silverado eléctrica. Tesla superó a todos, pues solo en el tercer trimestre se vendieron supuestamente (no hay datos oficiales) más de 16.000 unidades de la Cybertruck.RelacionadoEsta Tesla Cybertruck ha logrado colarse en Europa por la puerta de atrás como vehículo homologado
